body: @Blavo  I assume you have registered Glassfish 7.0.6 within NetBeans? Does this also happen, when you start the server within NetBeans or only when you deploy your project?

Restructured, added Changelog in a separate commit.
I have injected the whitespace handling into `LanguageClient` wrapper, so every `showQuickPick` message coalesces whitespaces and strips newlines.

G’day,

As I recall it, after I installed GF7 and restarted NB18 I was surprised not to be offered GF7 as a ’server’ option for a new Java web project. I had to add the Jakarta EE 10 API library to that project’s library list manually (from the list of available libraries). Since then my GF7 install is offered as a ’server’ option including in the new Enterprise application client that is the subject of the issue . So, in that sense, yes I ‘registered’ my GF 7.0.6 installation in NetBeans. 

The issue is with an enterprise application client. Attempting to run the client from within NetBeans results in a successful deploy but a failed run attempt. Being an EAC it can’t be run from within the server and isn’t run on server restart.

> 
> 
> @Blavo <https://github.com/Blavo> I assume you have registered Glassfish 7.0.6 within NetBeans? Does this also happen, when you start the server within NetBeans or only when you deploy your project?

@rpj0330 your bug report is quite confusing - at least for me. Please consider
* report only one problem per issue (it seems there are several within this one)
* things like "persistence errors" are not helpful in figuring out what's going on.  Please provide `Exceptions`, error messages from the server or even screenshots
* it's important to know the versions of every component which is involved in that issue. What's the version of glassfish? What's the version of payara?
* invest the time to prepare a step by step guide how to reproduce your issue
* if the NetBeans installation behave differently after reinstalling you should consider deleting NetBeans user and cache folders
Squashed to just have just changelog update separate.

From the log:
```
Insufficient disk space for extracting the installation data.
````

Do you have enough free space in your drive?

I'm no longer using Netbeans, but in the 10+ years I've used it under various versions of Windows it was the only application (using the JDK or otherwise) where I experienced this clipboard bug.

Consequently, I am pretty sure that the bug isn't in the JDK but in Netbeans proper.

I have two suggestions:

1. Someone should review all the above comments and summarize what we know in a single place.
2. Create an automated test (using `java.awt.Robot` or otherwise) that will reproduce this problem. This will allow you to reproduce the problem much quicker, and in a deterministic manner. This will also reveal whether the bug occurs intermittently or has 100% reproducible steps.

I'm confused - you mentioned this in the recent discussion post at #6272 but said there you'd got past the comparison method error in the JDK?!

As a workaround, try the community packages built with NBPackage instead - https://www.codelerity.com/netbeans/
OK, thanks!  Reproducible, and I assume a side effect of #5989 and #6216 - looking into it.  May need to revert that.

We need to revert or fix the code introduced here before we can build 19-rc4 (which will hopefully be our last release candidate).  See #6290 

We need to make sure the parent is a Frame or Dialog, and never a plain Window - see at https://github.com/openjdk/jdk/blob/master/src/java.desktop/share/classes/java/awt/Dialog.java#L676
cc/ @rkeen-siemens @errael - we need to decide whether to revert these changes or merge what is hopefully a fix for NB19.  Your input would be welcomed.
Reverting a crash in favor of a lockup isn't a great choice (but the lockup is probably less frequent).

Force pushed (again) because of failing test. Actually realised the test had been updated as part of #5989 and the update here behaves like the previous NetBeans code did. Putting back the old test line.
@errael well, the lockup is unlikely to be triggered in NetBeans rather than the platform. But have hopefully fixed this in #6294 while keeping the new parenting code anyway.

It's also related to #6289

There is a `View > IDE Log`. That would open the IDE log in a window. The file is in your case would be: `C:\Users\rlc\AppData\Roaming\NetBeans\18\var\log\messages.log`

It also seems that there is at least 2 different issue here. One is an NPE, the other would be a Memory Leak.

The log files could give guidance for fixing the NPE, however the memory leak would need an object allocation history and maybe a memory dump.

The first 50 lines of `jmap -histo <PID>` would get the heap histogram.

In Addition this was on the console. I don't think I can attached the heapdump.hprof file because it is 3.66 Gb.
If you need me to look for something in there I can try.

@asbachb I have mixed feelings here, but I doubt, that we see the same screw up again. I assume, that the next Jakarta EE version will retain its backwards compatibilty. The massive breaking going from JavaEE to JakartaEE was expected and if it is repeated, I assume, that the platform will die. So I assume that the question `isEjb40Supported` and `isEjb40LiteSupported` both can be answered positively for the next specification versions, because it is true. If they again break namespaces or packages, well, then yes, it will break again and IMHO validly so.

I'm not the one that did the work the last time round, so the opinions of @pepness, @juneau001, @jGauravGupta  and @OndroMih would be helpful.

Hi, my gut feeling is as long as the component version is supported by the latest Jakarta EE, it’s OK to assume that it will continue to be supported for future versions. In the worst case, older versions of Netbeans will generate code that will need to be fixed by the user and newer versions of NB will fix the behavior to return false for newer Jakarta EE versions that break the API. IMHO it’s better than not being able to generate any code. E.g. isEjb40Supported() would be OK as in this PR.

But for older versions, e.g. is Ejb31Supported, they should only return true for Jakarta EE versions that don’t break the API. In this case, Jakarta EE 9 is no linger compatible with EJB 3.1, so isEjb31Supported() would be true only for JavaEE 6-8 and Jakarta EE 8.

This way, we’d only need to fix Netbeans in case there’s another breaking change in Jakarta EE.
I agree, that way it will be easily for someone to experiment with lower or higher throughput. Will work on that too.
